ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: (1)Text was essentially a repetition of the the lectures, and while more content was present it was not presented any clearer, so served as a poor reference to improve understanding.

The class was a little bit slower paced than my other classes, but that wasn't necessarily a bad thing.I feel that I really learned the fundamentals of the certain sampling methods, and have already started applying them in my MESc masters project work. However, the end of the semester got a little rushed due to rescheduled classes from earlier in the semester, and the final project did not get assigned until finals period was beginning. I really would have benefited from in-the-field demonstrations of techniques that were learning about in class, and really feel that I missed an opportunity to solidify my understanding of the content from the last half of the class.

Question 12. This course provided students with very useful theoretical and practical tools to be used in forestry conservation, academic and research projects. None of conservation, academic and research projects would be conducted without estimating the samples to be applied in the process. The class provided related skills and knowledge to students throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Tim is very responsive to students' questions and general needs. The course had an overall feeling of being laid back, so there was not much stress associated with taking this course.

Great overview of those sampling methods which are generally only touched upon in intro statistics courses, and also provides some new ones. The course leaves you with a good intuition for when and why a certain sampling method might be called for.

The best aspects of this course were the assignments and home works on which students were working on for the whole semester. Every section of the course was sanctioned by a homework, which allowed students to deepen their understanding of the course. Also, the way the instructor commented students' works was very touching. Thus, students were encouraged and supported by the instructor to improve their skills and knowledge in the course anytime they needed it.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The lectures were NOT engaging, not to mention confusing. Especially as the notation used is not even necessarily universal, its utilization was a constant source of confusion, which could have been easily remedied with regular references to what each of the variables mean within the lecture text. Similarly, the text has essentially the same presentation of content as the lectures, so things that were not clear in one were not necessarily made more so by reading the other. While it was recommended for students to make our own "key" of the various variables used, I think it would be appropriate for the professor to provide this to students, as often in the text this is not clear, explanations are not always clear or linear, and small subtleties (eg cap or subscript)could mean very different things. For a student trying to learn the concepts being presented having to search through the text constantly in order to remember what a variable refers to (which is not always clear itself when it is explained) is an unnecessary draw on time that could be better devoted to understanding the conceptual material. More real-life examples, lectures that then demand students to work through problems in real time in class, rather than hours of discussion of greek letters in equations would be a vast improvement to help with understanding of concepts and applicability.

The course was not very useful to students outside of forestry. The material taught in this course should be expanded to include a broader range of methodologies or FES should introduce another course to do so.
The course moves slowly compared to other math or stat courses at FES.
More exercises
It would be good to have a file trip, where the use of different instruments and different sapling strategies can be applied

Since students in the class come from different background but interested in gaining important skills and knowledge to be applied in their conservation, research and academic projects, I would suggest to resolve many exercises (examples) in the class, if time allows, one per section, and continue the approach of one home work per section.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The theoretical conceptual lectures of this course need to be linked in a practical sense to usable applicable knowledge for practitioners, and I feel as though too much emphasis was placed on explanations of concepts and theory, but I still don't necessarily feel as though I have a firm grasp for on-the-ground sampling, or options for methodologies in actual studies. Examples discussed in lecture seemed to represent non-environmental data and very specific examples of environmental data (tree surveys) with little discussion of sampling that may occur for other kinds of data sets

Yes. The relationship between the class lectures, discussions and labs was effective. The course was designed in a way that there was a home work for every section of the course, which allowed students to improve their understanding of the course through these practical exercises.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Fulfills a sampling/statistics requirement for the MF.

At the beginning of the course, I thought it would fit in well with my overall program, but by the end I felt like it did not fit in at all since it was much more forestry-focused than I originally understood.
this is a classical topic in Forestry. for students that want to focused their car rear on Forestry or Ecology, this class should be mandatory.

Over the summer, I will be working on documenting a new forest to be assigned a conservation status. Animal species will be also assessed including their habitat. This course has provided me with needed tools to use in this process. As an Environmental manager, I will use skills and knowledge gained from this course to draw sound projects in conservation and sustainable development.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Fulfills a requirement and I was hoping to learn practical knowledge for sampling and research purposes

There have been many times in my work in which I had to select a sample for one reason or another. I wanted to become more confident in my ability to sample in an efficient and methodologically valid way. Intro stat courses don't provide you with a good basis for which method to use, or even how to correctly use a given method.
Sampling is the most important skills in forest inventory and biomass estimations
the topics included on this class are necessaries to my career
I took this course because I needed to fit the gaps I encountered in my professional duties, related to statistical designs and analysis.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not really. As mentioned earlier, I was expecting more practical use out of the course. Too much emphasis was placed on explaining equations and their derivations that I was left confused (as I was being presented with equations that I would never actually use in reality or multiple derivations and I would spend excessive time trying to understand which I'm actually meant to use from the notes and text, rather than being able to interpret the various implications of different sampling methods) and with less understanding/hands-on experience of what to do when actually conducting a study.
Yes
Perfectly
Yes, this class provided an excellent theoretical background, However, more practical work would complement this class
Yes, my expectations were met!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
Good team.
I have the chance to see how other students solved the problems, and compared it with my solutions.
NA

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Consider whether the sampling methodologies taught in this course would really be beneficial to your area of interest.
Take time to understand both the math and concepts/language. While the problem sets mostly test the former, the midterm tests the latter.

Very helpful - stats classes focus on how to evaluate data once you have it. This class shows you what you need to know to collect the data (although most of what's covered here is not as relevant if you want to get data on species that move around as opposed to stay stationary like plants).
They have to consider taking this class as it provides a well understanding of good and precise is your sample before you conduct your field work.
Students that want to focused their careers on Forestry and Ecology would find the necessaries told to design sampling projects with a statistical support.

I will encourage them to take the course. This course is very important as all conservation and research projects in science, including social sciences will require design and analysis of statistical manipulations.
